Award.AwardTitle: Degenerate Microlocal Methods in Geometric Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract of NSF Award DMS 0805529 (Rafe Mazzeo):

The PI's research focuses on a number of problems in geometric analysis involving degenerate elliptic or parabolic equations on stratified spaces. One theme is the search for canonical metrics on the class of compact iterated cone-edge spaces; special low-dimensional cases include a new analysis of Riemann surfaces with conic singularities, and more significantly, some robust deformation results for three dimensional polyhedra in space forms. Closely related is a project to determine the deformation theory of noncompact Einstein spaces modeled on noncompact symmetric spaces of general rank; this is a generalization of the theory of Poincare-Einstein metrics which has played a prominent role in many recent papers in conformal geometry, and also in string theory, where it appears as part of the AdS/CFT correspondence. Another project concerns minimal submanifolds of these Poincare-Einstein spaces, and in particular, in three-dimensional convex cocompact hyperbolic manifolds. The goal here is to define and study the variational properties of the renormalized area functional on the space of properly embedded minimal surfaces with embedded asymptotic boundary curves; this seems to be a natural context for studying the Willmore functional from differential geometry for surfaces with boundary. Finally, the PI has also been studying geometric evolution equations on singular spaces. The first case in terms of geometric simplicity is the generalization of the curvature flow from the setting of closed embedded curves to that of networks of curves; the goals are to establish a good existence theory for the flow, to examine questions of nonuniqueness and to prove long-time existence to a Steiner network.

To put this work into a broader context, most work in geometric analysis is in the setting of geometric objects which are smooth, i.e. do not have corners, edges or other singularities.
However, spaces with singularities appear naturally and very frequently in geometry, physics and other applications, and it is natural to try to extend the methods and results of geometric analysis to this broader class of objects. However, the appropriate tools from analysis and partial differential equations do not exist in this generality, so a major part of the work needed is to extend these techniques to spaces with singularities. This has been a major endeavour of the PI throughout his career. The specific problems on which he is now working involve refined questions such as the existence and nature of optimal metrics, or shapes, on these singular spaces, and the study of evolution equations which continuously deform such a space into one of these optimal shapes. On smooth spaces, these questions have been some of the principal directions of research in geometric analysis, but their analogues in this singular setting have not been studied in any systematic way. Another problem involves the study of a renormalized version of the surface area of a class of optimal (minimal) surfaces inside a space with constant negative curvature. This is an action functional which has been studied intensively in string theory.
One final part of this PI's work is of an educational nature: he is the founder and director of a residential summer program (SUMaC), held at his institution each year, which is directed toward highly motivated and talented high school students to encourage their continued study of mathematics. This program is now in its fourteenth year of operation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project centers on a set of mathematical tools under development by the PI which are well-suited to study certain singular analytic phenomena which arise in many places in his main field, geometric analysis, but which also appear in areas as diverse as mathematical physics and population biology. These phenomena are related to the solutions of certain classes of partial differential equations which are used to model geometric, physical or biological phenomena where the common underlying feature is that the space where these solutions are defined exhibit singularities, e.g. have boundaries, corners, cone points or edges. These features make the equations being studied fall outside of well-known techniques and necessitate the introduction of new ideas and approaches.  The PI is very interested both in the continued development of these new techniques, and in finding interesting problems where they may be of use.  The outcomes of this award show that both of these goals have been met successfully.

To be more specific, the key outcomes include new results about the existence and deformability or rigidity of interesting geometric shapes, such as polyhedra in Euclidean space and how they are related to the angles along their edges, and other geometric objects called Kaehler-Einstein metrics, which are central objects of study in complex geometry.  Another very different set of outcomes is related to the PI's study of the diffusion processes which arise in some old models in population biology which model the concentration of various genotypes in a large population with fixed mutation rates and genetic drift. This has led to an incisive analysis of the properties of solutions that arise in this model. The PI has initiated some new ways to study the evolution of nonclosed surfaces under the so-called Ricci flow, which is a dynamical process which attempts to allow a geometric object to gradually deform into a more regular shape. Yet another direction has involved study of the renormalized action, a term coming from string theory, of surfaces which minimize surface area in an ambient space of constant negative curvature. A surprising outcome of this investigation is the fact that this renormalized action is the same as a rather classical geometric action which measures the bending energy of a surface, which has even been applied in the study of materials in mechanical engineering. A key theme underlying all of these investigations in one way or the other is the identification and analysis of analytic conditions near the boundaries or singular regions of the objects being studied which make the stationary or dynamical process in question be well-posed.
